Description: Head of a terracotta figurine of a male youth (kouros). Mould-made. Hair above forehead arranged in waves, vertically subdivided by two grooves on the right and one on the left. No structure to hair hanging down beside head and back.Broken off at the neck and shoulders along the original line where it was once attached to the body (or other feature); an ancient hole and breaks covering the whole of the top of the head where something was once attached, i.e. carried on the head. Face mouldmade, back handmade; hollow; chin and tops of both ears chipped, crack in lower left part of face and neck. Light orange-brown (5YR7/6 - 7.5YR8/6) fine clay with no obvious mica, few small shiny black inclusions and few small burnt-out holes, smooth brownish slipped surface.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by McManus Galleries, Dundee. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel from Rhodes, now in the British Museum (Higgins 1954, no.49) dated to the mid 6th century BC, but with finer eyes and hair details and in a micaceous fabric. Parallel from Samos dated to the 6th century BC (Tsakos 2007, 194, pl.26.4). Findspot 'town' is recorded in the 1975 register. Neither from the documentation in Dundee nor from the Egypt Exploration Fund (EEF) distribution lists does it become clear when the objects from Naukratis (and Tell Dafana) entered the Museum, as neither of the sites is mentioned in them. Objects in the McManus Galleries were (re-)registered in 1975 after the loss of the original registers (some of which were later recovered). According to the museum's yearly Reports, the Galleries received objects from the Egypt Exploration Fund (EEF) in 1888, 1889/90, 1892 (not all Reports were available to us for consultation), and every year from 1900 until 1914, but these donations are usually not recorded in the registers. Donations were made either directly by the Egypt Exploration Fund (EEF), (1889/90 and 1914), per Amelia Edwards (1888 and 1889/90), or per the local secretaries of the Egypt Exploration Fund (EEF): Rev. Colin Campbell (1892 until 1905), Mr. J. Maclauchlan (1906), and Mr. A.H. Millar (1907-1913). Additional donations were made by the British School of Archaeology in Egypt in 1914. Tsakos, K. 2007. Die stadt Samos in der geometrischen und archaischen epoche, in Corbet, J. Frühes Ionien : eine Bestandsaufnahme; Panionion-Symposion Güzelçamlı, 26. September - 1. Oktober 1999 Milesische Forschungen. sches Archäologisches Institut, Mainz, 189-200.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.034) (Phase 1)
